Very many many thanks to Dear Nettie for her good letters What shall be done for her health I feel really anxious about it. I think C's remedy "thorough most,, in small quantity, cold, is a good tonic I dont know whether it is the best. I would try for a while wearing flannel especially round the bowels have ye ever try'd a wet towel and warm flannel over it when a
Completed

Diarrhea first come on - that would be Eliabs remedy. Do Dear Nettie write me more particularly about your health - if you dont get better soon & babe seem to be healthy perhaps you had better wean him if you have good Cows milk it might probably be done without hurting him March or April would be a better time if there is no necessity why do you have him wear Socks do you not have to tie them round the ankle to make them stay on if so he would be better without them as it must in some degree stop the circulation & the feet will be colder. take the time? together than if bare foot. I do want you should be well for I want to tax you a great deal in writing every thing about Charles for I perhaps get much from himself
Completed

Mother Milo
Feb. 23 1854

                                                                                                                   Cedar Grove Feb. 23rd 1854 
My Dear So   O how it does Storm & Blow. It has snowed all day and the wind has been all the while piling it up the Snow is very deep - we have steady cold weather sometimes very cold ever since the 20th of Dec. except a little rain twice just enough make a sharp crust on the snow.  Eliab had a letter from Uncle Pel. a few days ago they are all well as usual speaking of the weather brought it to my mind

Sam'l called here last monday eve on his way into the woods he has rather a hard time this winter tho he is making money perhaps - & perhaps not for he has to give enormous prices for what he buys. And labor is exceedingly scarce & high. It would seem that every body capable of swinging an ax is off in the woods John Hodgkins was in here said his Charles was going into the woods gets 12 dollars a month. Mr. Rider says that he shall want James as Ellridge is in the woods and Mills is going to Foxcroft to school but that he must stay if we cant get somebody else. I ask'd Mr. H. about George who is now at Hector Sargents he said if Mrs. S. did not conclude to hire him he might come here till Spring opens for 7 dollars a month said he had rather he would work he than anywhere else but talks of taking him to old town with him bye & bye if he can get 12, a month. Said something about his working here all summer if you were going to be at home etc. I was talking with Mr. Livermore about the work here in the spring he is always full of business you know but said if you should have a stout yoke of oxen he should like to change work a good deal - by the way why dont you tell
Completed

at what time you expect to come home - whether you come before the the time for Spring work or not I suppose it would be well to get oxen. And hire George if he can be had for reasonable wages - for there seems to be now no prospect that you can have Ellridge or either of the Hants - or indeed any body presently there may be when the men come out of the woods but they say common kind of hands get 26,00 a month if so they wont work very cheap on a farm. I ask'd Charlie what I should write to you he says tell Faver he better come before we plant. But I guess George & James & I can get it done - he is naturally a good boy but he has learn'd a great many naughty ways this winter Jane has been to school & she has grown reckless om school & saucy - she doesn't heed Albina's authority at all - we think of having her go away just as soon as we can find a place for her

 Is your work harder that you are doing there than you usually do winter? Feb. 26th we have just received letters from you dated Feb. 12 Your letters seems to come pretty regularly I cant think why dou dont get letters oftener we have none of us been remiss about writing to you. But perhaps you have reciev'd ever so many before now. I hope S. Conant will be beneficial to Isaac and do well for himself. I was surprised to hear that he was there the worst fault I know of him (tho' I know but little about him) is that he is apt to talk large . He is I guess rather an excentic character  tho' pretty good in the main. His Father has made his will gave S. only 50,00 & Hervey all the rest. Sam'l is big enough to do something but I should think him not so fit for any Mechanical business the children have been unwell with colds Josie was quite sick a few days but is better now Charlie cried with the earache considerable one night and Mary is very much troubled with her teeth she has got 6 of her fore teeth and one double tooth just cut  and thro' I hope you have got many of our letters & will write & tell all what to about the farm etc.
Completed

26th

My Dear Son Isaac & Nettie I feel & have felt a great deal of anxiety about your health tho' Charles writes me that you are both improving in health I perceive by the ill looking Dags you sent that you are making large drafts on your constitution you think you cannot leave there, till that road is done what if your health should be entirely broken down & lost before that time what good would your road or the pay for it do you in lieu of it
 I rejoice to know that Antoinette is coming away I think it an excellent plan for her to come away early in the season and stop with Ann till she comes (the first of June)
  Why cant you come there during the hottest of weather, what if the road should be a year longer in building & save the health of all the Laborers on it - which of all the Engineers would be willing to give his life for the whole rad. Do try your influence to stop the whole proceeding for a while in the hot weather
 We have all been almost sick with Colds. I had a very severe cold in the first of the winter. But had got over it & went to Bangor thinking to stay thro' the coldest of the weather. But came home because when Josie was sick he and baby have been sick enough to be very troublesome and require a great deal of care & attention but Charles need not be anxious about them we are being very careful and nursing them up nicely probably they'll be all well long before he'll know they have been unwell. I dont know but I shall get to dislike this Climate in the winter as bad as that in the summer - there are 4 sick at Mr. Livermore - young David has been confin'd all winter with lame knee. Mr. H. Sargent is very sick yet. I spent a week very pleasantly at Bangor with Lucy Eliab & Maria - every is so nice & comfortable there I've had a cold & cough ever since I came home but it doesn't make me sick.
Completed

Charles dont write whether he is glad he went there or not I suspect his chance for sleeping has been some of the time not exactly to his taste he has been particularly partial to a good soft bed. I think that if he had stay this winter he would have been sick most assuredly.

   I guess Sam'l lumbering operations have been extensive this winter as last or more so I think he must have had rather a hard time getting his supplies into the woods - there was a short time before the snow was deep enough for good Sledding he said it cost him 40,00 to get a ton of Hay hauld from Milo to his Camps & that his oxen would it up in three days - while I was at Bangor he mention'd Settling with 3 mean with whom he had dealings the amount of which was between 50 & 60 thousand dollars. I guess Eliab & his wife are esteem'd & valued in Bangor & their society courted i.e. they are envited into the first & best company there is there - members of the Corban etc.. But I fear he has a "hard row to hoe" (Genteel poverty you know) it seems to me however that they are both determin'd to be very economical and keep aloof from the great parties. Lucy wrote me they (E. & wife) were invited to Walter Browns with about 500 others they were not going. Do my Dear Daughter Antoinette be careful of your health & of the dear little one not by keeping too close and being too choise of him I suppose infants grow strong and healthy by being permitted to creep and wallow about the floor to suit themselves provided they are not exposed to dampness or sudden cold. But I know nothing about it his constitution may be very different from our northern children neighbor Ricker for instance who are barefoot out in the snow or any way i.e. the little ones that dont go to school

I suppose it now be too selfish to indulge the wish for you to come here before you see Dunbarton but the time will seem long I hope Isaac can come here too I must stop now or get another sheet of papers.
[right-hand side]I doubt whether you can read this written so bad & in the evening.
Completed

Mother. Milo
March 1st 1854

                                                                                                                   Cedar Grove Milo March 1st 1854

My Dear Children

     Since it is my birth day I will just begin a letter to you. 3 years more & I shall have pass'd my three score & ten. Surely God has been good to me. I can look back on a life of mercies - Many very Signal Mercies and blessings. But what poor returns - What a poor stupid rebellious unprofitable Servant I have been. Griefs trials & vicisitudes many -But all from a kind Fathers hand - and less of Chastening than we deserv'd

March 2nd We are about here Comfortably well the children have been unwell  good deal in the last 3 weeks as you will have heard before you get this. The Snow is about even with the tops of the fences perhaps not quite so deep on average in the fields The weather is so warm that one could stay outdoor without freezing

   John Kittredge keeps the Colt yet it seems tame as any old horse he call'd here just now on his way to Charleston to borrow a whip
Completed

Charles will loose something on his colts in consequence of his absence. I guess John takes good care of the one he has & they say, & Albina supposes he does not pay for her keeping. But I'm sure they do ride about this winter. He got cork'd pretty bad once but I guess they mean to be careful and not hurt him.   School closes tomorrow & James can devote more time & attention to the Creatures if he can stay here but his folks want him at home Ellridge is in the wood & Mills at Foxcroft and Mr. Rider is some lame - he cannot have George Uncle Mark is sick and cant come back, but I guess there'll be some way for us It seems possible from they say that Ellridge would come & work here next summer for money enough but it would take a great fdeal hadn't C. better get S. Conant to come home with him & work here unless as I suppose he has got to go back to his own family - probably it would be too hard for him or C. to stay with you thro' the hot weather if they could leave home so long. All kinds of produce is high now it will not do for farmers to neglect their farms.
Charlie is a real good honest little fellow very good to mind but somewhat fiery. A hasty fretful or
Completed

impatient word rouses his ire - last night his Mother told him to right off to bed, whereas he thought he had not sufficiently warm'd his feet - he obey'd but mutter'd out - Soon as I get to be a man I shall got right away from here I shan't live with you.

   I suspect your precious little one is, among so many folks talk'd to & play'd with too much taken too much notice of - not so happy so healthy or so pretty for it is it so  I have thought that little ones do better to keep them comfortable besure but leave them in quiet to their own resources they will naturally play enough to make them tired, without being induced to it

Phew! it is nonsense for me to give advice about the boy but I want to see him & it is some relief to talk about him  You say you are buying land out there what good will it do you. Surely you never'll got there to live. Who'll take care of it for you

 Charles dont write whether he likes that country nor when, or whether he is ever coming home

I am somewhat apprehensive that his farm will have to lay common till he does come for want of some one to put up fences etc. - is he likely to earn enough there to countervail the kings? damage - I don't
Completed

care if he dont for he will get some more stow'd in the garret if not in the purse which may be more valuable in the end if he can only have his health I feel anxious about that & and all the rest of you

  I think I shall send this to the P.O. today if I have a chance - and I confidently expect a letter, or letters from some of you tonight
  My Cold & cough is very much better than it was. I've done nothing to speak of since I came home but help take care of the children am trying to learn Charlie to read I could not percieve that he had learn'd any since last summer - he seems to be trying a little himself now - he does not learn easy but he is a stirring chap - says he is going to be a Real kind man
  It has snow'd 3 or 4 days in the last week but the sun shines warm & pleasant today probably the snow will begin to sweat? some before a great while
 May God be with you all & bless you & keep you in health and peace and comfort and return you all with joy to your Mother
Completed

Mother Milo - Apr 12, 1854
DuQuoin  Apr 25 1854
Cedar Grove 
April 2nd 1854
My Dear Children  If you could just fly over my house as a flock of wild geese did most a fortnight ago you might see - Snow - Snow - The earth aparently dead and buried - her winding Sheet so thick and bound so tight - there seems no signs of life or hope of her resurrection here if not for the blessed promise "Seed time & harvest shall not fail"
It rain'd some yesterday and the snow has settled so that the tops of the fences begin to appear
I had a letter from Anna last week dated March 14 one from Lucy and Maria dated 27th all well  Eliab gone to New Haven on business - Sam'l I hear is up in the wood I suppose to close up his winters business & pay off his men - It is well that I have not much care & solitude on my own particular account for Albina has enough for both & she cannot bear as some can. She often comes to me with difficulties and disasters, Saying Charles must come home I cant endure so much care &c  I have to exert my mind in smoothing away and encouraging &c. We have not had efficient help & care about the barn. - Charles had a very fine flock of 75 sheep but for want of proper care & feed - they are rather poor, may lose most all their lambs - many little things you know will go away, where there is not a noise heard to direct - during the dreadful storm that we wrote about last week one had only little Summer Kittredge here & Albina went to the barn every day - She thinks if Charles was only here every thing would be just right - I tell her he might have been sick, if here, & we, as much troubled to get help, -- However we are all well & comfortable, and I do not yet regret Charles's going there if it does subject him to becoming lost it may benefit him other ways, he needed some change
Completed

Sam'l is here tonight April 3rd  He has bought out Pendleton & Ross gave Furber & Metcalf, notes for 10000,
I suppose they'll write you all about it - In regard to Charles's coming home soon - we want to see him enough but the winter will be over & gone & the singing of birds will come sometime - and tho' we can conjure up a thousand difficulties & disasters which may happen - the probability is, I think we shall get along quite comfortably - We have Mr. Willard Frosts son here now & he would perhaps stay thro' the summer for wages enough - tho' if Walter Rider will come it will be better - tho he is an invalid somewhat & his wife & child must come with him - Sam'l think that good smart men will get from 15, to 18, or 20, a month
I cannot but feel concern'd for you & Antoinette in regard to your health would that whole Rail Road if you could own it all be worth as much to you as your health and your wife's health -- I have some fears tho' I suppose she is coming east soon that the change from that climate to the N.H. Hills if too sudden may be too much for her  will she not stop a few weeks with Anna  She expects to come here in first part of June
How I do want to see you all - I suppose I shall stay here till Charles comes home but the time will seem long dont let him stay till he gets the "shakes"
Anna wrote that she is planning to have me go home with her but I dont think it will be expedient this summer from your affectionate Mother
To I.S.M.
Completed

Milo  June 26 54
July 8 54
Cedar Grove  June 26th 1854
My Dear Son,
Your letter dated 11th june I got 22nd - How quick you did get b ack I should think it would be very hard travelling so fast & continually but you say you feel better for travelling - Doubtless you will feel lonely - you will know how to pity Albina  She complains bitterly - I asked her if she thought it was harder for her to be parted from one of my chhildren so long than for me - she thought it was hard enough - I suppose Charles will have left you, before you get this - If he has not send him along at once for his Hay will be fit to cut about as early as usual - and he must repair his Barn a good deal before he can first hay into it but more than all that we are afraid of his getting sick
Sam'l & Lucy, Nettie, Sabra, & the dear babies came up Wednesday 14th & return'd last the next Monday - So short a visit I did nt have time hardly to begin to enjoy them I feel quite unreconcil'd to it - I did so want to keep little Mayo till he could be acquainted and get to love me as my little ones do here - he is a good little boy physically smarter than Percie
Completed

But what a pensive sad expression there is on his countenance  it struck me so at first I could hardly refrain from tears - Sabra seems good & kind enough but I do always feel so sorry for babes if they have to be entrusted to any body but their mother no one can feel for them & sympathize with all their little wants and feelings like a mother, it must have been very hard for Antoinette & baby too that she has been so unwell - I guess she is gaining finely - She looks as well & as fleshy as when she was here 2 years ago but I suppose she is not near as Strong  Percie seems not near as strong as Mayo but I should think his mind more develop'd probably because Lucy has been so constantly every moment devoted to him talking to him watching & guiding every thought & feeling - But how thankful you ought to be that you have such a wife & that your boy has just such a Mother if her health is spar'd he cannot but be just about what you would wish him to be
You & indeed all my children are so good to me that it makes me cry when I think of it & bless God too for his wonderful kindness - your offer of money for travelling expenses is generous very
Completed

but I should not feel myself justified in accepting it for various reasons - one is I have not spent more than half of the 100, you sent me a year ago - no not one quarter of it for myself - I grudge feel that money ought to be us'd for some better purpose what I spend for myself - I love and enjoy travelling very exceedingly but the benefit cannot be so much at my age - as my mind & memory are so much impair'd - I'm so soon to pass away - I cannot have the pleasure of enjoying over & over again by recollection what passes now as what pass'd when I was younger  Still I think I have just as keen a relish for whatever is beautiful & good but my mind is like a seive every thing passes thro' and is gone - I have as much satisfaction in reading perhaps more than I ever us'd to but I cant remember so as to tell over what I read  I have lately been reading over & over "Saturday Evening" & enjoy'd it much especially the last part of it
Oh! dear how I always do get to writing about myself its all I, I before I am aware of it
Bea Brown died last sabbath  I call'd on Mrs. Lee on my return from Brownville she expects her three sisters to visit & her Brother at Bucksport who with herself are all over seventy I believe
Completed

The Trees & the grass have grown so very fast this 2 or 3 weeks past you can hardly imagine how beautiful they do look such a deep, lively rich variety of green - The trees in front of the House never look'd so beautiful before - perhaps in gratitude for the attention you & E. gave them when you were here - grass is said to be much water kill'd tho Walter says it is not on our farm - it look very finely from here tho' not ripe yet the 'mower might well 'fill his scythe'
Sabbath 25th  Today the leader of the Choir of singers & Superintendent of Sabbath school Mr. Wetherbee attended the Universalist Meeting forenoon & afternoon - but went into the Baptist house at noon to attend to his duty as Superintendent 
I have almost no communication or acquaintance with the people in this town - Tis wrong to live so in regard to social intercourse with the neighbors especially I am aware the fault is mine that I have been easily guilty - tho I have n't realiz'd it as the time pass'd along and now dont know how to remedy it or atone for it
I can hardly believe I am really misanthropic tho' perhaps I must own that I am naturally unsocial - yet I know I do enjoy such society as I like exceedingly
O what blessedness there is in contemplating the deep the rich the unspeakable gift the Blood of Christ that cleanseth from all Sin  Pray for me my son that I may be cleans'd purified wholy santified and made meet for the inheritance -
Antoinette calculates  to wait till Anna goes back & I'm so sorry she did nt stay here longer - We are looking for Charles to come the last of this week - As you wont have a wife & baby to talk to this summer you will of course write a good deel to her and I hope I shall hear from you often as you make it convenient too
God be with you & bless you & keep you from all evil
Completed

Dear Isaac   Tho' I have sent one letter to you that you have not answer'd I feel inclin'd to tell you about our disappointment at not seeing Charles - there have been so many little things that have been waiting for him to remedy and rectify - nothing great to be sure only that Walter is sick & somewhat discourag'd and Albina is so impatient so unreconcil'd & fretted it perhaps makes him more so
I dont know what to do I've been talking  talking to try to reconcile all round but I am only an old woman and not worth minding & am a great deal too apt to speak my opinion I often think I will reform in that thing but shall keep failing to do it
Charles is apt to hang on and stick to any piece of work he gets about just because he wants to see the result or end there of and he and perhaps you for him, ought to guard against it but what I feel the most about is the fear that he will get sick -
Completed

We are expecting Dr. DeWitt and his wife and daughters day after tomorrow  I think I shall go back with her as far a Bangor and perhaps take Charlie with me  A wants to have him go if Lucy is not well enough to have him 
Anna wrote to me that she wants me to go home with her had I better or not - I want to be at Bangor this fall - but perhaps should never have so good an opportunity to go, as I could go with them and return with you when you come
But Maria expects to be sick next month and tho' I could do no good I should rather be about here & E. & M. seem to want I should
Charlie needs a father or some one to govern him mildly but with firmness - he is a good boy but now he goes to school he has a great many uncouth & naughty ways & dont mind his Mother so quick as he should sometimes
Completed

I feel sad about it that I could n't have that dear little Conie Mayo longer I did love him so but did n't have him long enough to get him to love me - but you will bring him & his mother here again in the fall
There are scores of reasons for Charles's being at home but if he feels sure that it is better all things consider'd for him to be there we ought not to be so selfish as to want to hasten his return before the time that he thinks best - tell him to consider & be sure and be careful of his health - one of his reasons for staying - that Peaches would be ripe by & bye; seemd quite ridiculous when A feels so anxious to have him come home
Completed

Charles has pull'd up a tall dead cedar tree & with much labor has set it up in four different places successively for a liberty pole he is all the time driving at something but without much stability or design
Albina has a letter partly written to Charles but is not intending to send it till she has one from him which she is expecting next wednesday mail
do write often and particularly I fear I shant know not much about Charles after I go from home as he will send all his letters here
Written sideways:'
Mother
Milo July 9 1854
July 29, 1854
Completed

Cedar grove Milo July 25th /54
My Dear boys
We are all in good health - It has been cloudy & rainy a little & we are not at Man at work  Walker is here but not able to work - Dr DeWitt & wife & daughter return'd here this evening from Brownville  All the household are asleep as I suppose but I - I happen to be thinking of you that are far away not without fear that you are sick this hot weather  & so I have arisen from my bed & lit my candle to tell you of it -Albina does "mourn in her complaint and make a noise" because she is so disappointed that Charles did not come home - indeed she has been as it were constantly disappointed ever since May or June for she would in spite of me keep expecting him week after next or next week all the time - I dont see but we are all getting along tolerably comfortably & are likely to be except that A. feels so bad sometimes she is some what chicken hearted - She really cannot bear with any "fortitude so much as most people you & C. must consider that and one other thing i.e. the probability of getting sick you know you got the fever & ague the first summer you were there  what reason can you have for thinking that Charles will not - & N.B. I make this particular request not only that you both be very careful of your health but that you both try to console and pacify Albina and especially tell as near as you can just how long C. intends to stay  She has now
Completed

set the time that he will certainly be at home in August. I know it is hard fro her but cheifly because of her peculiar temperament she is naturally impatient & easily overcome by any thing difficult or disagreeable I think she does try very much to get the better of it & is to be pittied. The Children all do well & she has every think as comfortable as could be expected Walter is well enough to do the chore about house and take care of every thing

   My Son Dr. De Witt seems to be a very fine man I like him much & perhaps am a little proud of him haven't I a first rate half dozen of Sons "any way" or 1/4 of a doz. at any rate where will you find three "likilier" folks than Mr. Rider DeWitt and Furber the Dr. says he wouldn't be hir'd at any price to live & work where Mr. Rider does because of the flies 

26th  Mr. Rider & Mr. Kittredge & their wives have been here this afternoon. Mr. De Witt & folk expect to go to Bangor tomorrow. I expect to go friday or Saturday

 We rather expected a letter from Charles yesterday Do let me hear from you often.

[upside down] Mother Milo   July 25 1854
Ducoin Aug 8. 1854
Completed

Mother Aug. 7 54 
poor little Percie is very sick the dear little boy has not been well all summer and Lucy is very much exausted & run down She has had a very hard time this summer She could not get your help her energy of mind and body have been too severely taxed if Percie get better she'll soon get rested but oh! if he should not -- But the Dr. talks encouragingly & he has a little appetite today we hope the worst is over - that none can tell 
we have had a long spell of hot dry weather not dry enough to hurt the corn I guess 
July 28th the day I came down here the corn was tassl'd out & it looked a beautiful dark green color & has all the time grown finely tho' it was planted late  In regard to the ? I got Sam'l to enquire the price he finds that it is very low 25 cents only for unwash'd perhaps it will fetch more at Foxcroft. I've been reading a letter you sent to Eliab Dated July 23rd you say that S. Conant has started for home I am glad of it but I have some fears that I shall hear he is sick he is so nervous & anxious
Completed

like her mother. No if he should be sick & die I should probably not hear anything about it for they will not write Oh! how can you live in so much dust and not weather & you have to ride a good deal too I suppose How glad I shall be when you get releas'd from your bondage in Egypt. Anna insists that I shall go to Elyria & spend the winter possibly I may if any body happens to be going to take care of me but I am to old to attempt to go alone anywhere I dont know but she would have compel'd me to go with her if it had not been that Maria so soon expecting.  her wish is that I should first become acquainted by having a set of false teeth. It certainly is a great happiness to me to do anything for the gratification of my children but that would be a little more thanI could ? willingly come up to

 I had a letter from Nettie last week I must write to her soon. I am afraid Charles is too anxious about getting money. Money is useful somehow but cannot confer happiness. O do consider & try to make C. consider how short the time is and Eternity Eternity how best

write to your Mother
Completed

Bangor August 7th

My Dear Dear boys, I feel exceedingly anxious to hear from you I have written you 3 letters I believe certainly 2 since I have had any from you

 Albina & I both wrote the day that she had your letter containing your decision to stay longer I have written 2 or 3 time since & she has every week - I dont know what to say to you Charles about staying so long - there are reasons enough why you need to be at home some of which I will mention one is Walters wife expects to be sick in Nov. or Dec. and he talks that he wants to go to provide a place to live. I dont see why he would not be content to stay where he is as he can not do much work and has no home but his wife wants to be keeping house however it is very natural that he should want to know just what you would be willing to give etc. etc. He painted the house one over in the spring except the back side and the piazza then it was time to do something else - or he was not well enough - there is some paint left which is drying all up - and numerous things might be thought of which you need to attend to - none of very great moment but 

[top of letter upside down]You ought perhaps to let Albina know just how long you intend to stay & endeavor to make her feel reconciled to it. It is possible that Lucy or Almeda will take Charlie bye & bye a while Do write to me
Completed

but the great thing as it appears to me is the risk you run of being sick & the disappointment and distress Albina has about it. I am so apprehensive that one or perhaps both of you are sick even now - we hear so much about the Cholera & besides how do you expect to escape having the fever & ague if you come from that warm climate just as the cold weather commences here - you ought to consider well Albinas feeling and in some way get her more reconciled to it, or else come right home
I want to know more what your expectations are plan are - if Isaac has got to be there all winter & sends for Nettie as he intends could you not come home and arrange matters & go back again with her - if you think it so greatly for your advantage to be there - but is it so - or is it partly because of your prosperity to keep staying where you are wherever it is. If it were not for Albinas feeling so bad and the fear of your being sick I should want you to stay on Isaacs account
[left-hand side across page] I dont know how you ought to manage with Walter he certainly has an easy time with George to do the work & as he has no place of his own I should think he would be glad to stay there all winter whether you come home, or not, but there ought to be some understanding about on what terms perhaps
Completed

Mother & Lucy [[Lucy crossed out]
Aug. 24 1854

                                                                                                                           Bangor Aug 24. 1854

My Dear boys     Am very much oblig'd to you Isaac for your letter of Aug. 13th I am very glad - & thank you very much for writing to me. I do think it a very great blessing that you have both been so well. I fear we are not duly thankful for it, & our other innumerable blessings

  I cam here July 28th poor little Percie has been sick almost all the time since. He has not been so sick but he would take notice & play a little every day - but to play about on the floor or take care of himself he has not an hour this 3 or 4 weeks he is very poor & pale continues bad state of the bowels & teething weighs 18 1/2 lbs
   You say you ought to travel about I think I do some I certainly dont stay in one place so much as Sister Conant does. I travel from Milo to Bangor & back pretty often - that's as far as I dare venture alone. Should really like to go to Dunbarton to Elyria
  you tell about coming east after your family - what do you mean - you dont think to take Antoinette & baby away out there just to stay next winter do you - such a hard and 

[left-hand side across letter] Charlies "took on" badly when he learn'd that his Father was going to stay longer said to me Grandmother write to Father to come right home - as soon as he gets your letter tell him I cant wait only two more weeks
Completed

expensive journey with a baby - I am sorry for you "but then it is nothing to California - Suppose you were to be gone 3 or 4 years - Why you have not been four months from your family yet" and you have only one Child to leave & C. has three & what adds exceedingly to all the rest with Albina is she has the care of housekeeping - family affairs &c. &c. She does feel very much troubled & distressed says her heart will break - finally I do suppose & I believe we all do that C ought to have come home last Spring - whether it will do for him to come now on account of his health I dont know. I doubt whether he ought to stay on account of the money he can get - for he could get wages enough here common Irishmen get here in Bangor from 2,50 to 300, a day & hard to get help at all - beside Charles expenses & losses are great at home - but the greatest consideration is that Albina takes it so hard I think that any other of my six girls would get along with it with more fortitude
It does seem as if Walter might consider it a good chance? that he has there even if he gets not much besides the board of himself & family as he has no other home & cannot work - Albina wrote me that "Charles gives him a good chance but she did not tell what
It does seem also as if Albina might brace herself to endure "the care & trial" of C.'s being gone a while longer & perhaps she would rather than have him come just as the cold weather commences & make him sick
ever loving Mother
Completed

Bangor Aug 27th/54
My very Dear Boy, I will just inform you that you have a little niece born Saturday morning Aug 26th, 7 1/2 oclock weighed 7lbs - both mother & baby not merely comfortable but smart Maria says she could come down stairs this morning as well as not - they think it is all owning to the use of sitz bathes that she is so smart & well - but probably she will not feel so well a few days hence as she does now
We think Percie is better but he has been better & worse again to many times. he has not been so any day except he on two, when he was so sick 2 weeks ago but he would look back about & play a little- but cannot go alone - tho' he did a little when I first came here. Lucy has had a hard time this summer She looks now more like a ghost than a well person. She cannot recruit himself very much till Percie gets better I try to help her some but you know the mother is all in all for a sick child tho' he is very contented with me if she is not in sight
Completed

Mother wants me to write, but I have written so lately, than there seems to be little else to write but the news, and that Mother has written. The little damosel up stairs is fat & plump, but I can by no means call her fair?- she is extremely modest and blushes scarlet red all the time. I have written to Anna, Nettie to. We hope to heard from you soon. I had a dear letter from Nettie a day or two since. Poor little Percie does not seem so well today, but his teeth must come through soon. Tis sabbath, warm, sultry, P.P. feels miserably, as does Mother, as do I. Mr. Clarke from Hartford preaches this afternoon. The baby is a day & a half old & Mallie says she could come down stairs as well as I could! She is very well. We are a little 'fraid we said too much in our last latter about Charles'
Completed

staying - it was only on Albina's account, and we wrote to her to counteract it when she next wrote, if she felt to. Commencement this week - some of the strangers here today. Mr. Crane, from N.Y. City preached this morning. Do write often because we feel greatly anxious for your health. With much love, Sister Lucy.
Completed

Mother Bangor Sept 27, 1854
Oct 7
Sept 27 1854 Bangor
My Dear boy,  We have just received letters from you both  Dated Sept 17th  O how glad I am & how I thank you for writing so often - Albina sent me her letter too from Charles of Sept. 10th  I think Charles must have been puzzled & tried about coming home  Lucy & I were very sorry we wrote so much about his coming home  Should n't of if it had not been for Albina (she is not a suitable person to leave) it seems as if she has been comfortably situated except 2 or 3 weeks last month if it were not for this one idea (that seem'd to possess her mind entirely) "Charles must come home"  Walter has talked & I suspect pretended some about staying but inside I think he has wanted to stay all the while will perhaps ask more than C will be willing to give, he & George do have a very easy time
You speak about our going to Dunbarton how I wish we could I should really like to but it is not at all likely that Percie will be well enough before the weather will be to cold
Completed

me think he really is recovering now but is very feeble cannot walk or play about on the floor at all - it takes one of us all the time to take care of him - Lucy holds out wonderfully but she looks as if she could n't hold up her head or keep her eyes open - but she'll soon recruit as Percie gets well
Eliab is gone to Boston, he & P talk some about parting - I expect from their talk that they are to have very "tight" times about money - good many others in the same predicament - water so low not much sawing no freight for vessels &c. Rather bad for Eliab to be setting up housekeeping just at this time as it must take considerable money - he has been paying rent for his house (15'0,$ a year) since the first of this month I believe expects to move from here in a week or two
Maria & baby getting along nicely  she expects her eldest sister to come and help her about "setting up" housekeeping and that her youngest sister will come and
Completed

spend the winter with her
Dont you think that Charles's health will suffer if he comes home just as the cold weather commences - he is needed at home to put things to rights & I should be very glad he is coming if it was not for the fear I have about his health
They will have done all the Harvesting I guess for there was very little to do  the dry weather and the frost I suppose kill'd the Corn and most of the Oats - Albina said Walter & George were cutting down the alders just below the knowls by that little old bridge for firewood - I told her that the 12, a month & six dollars for board that Georges labor would cost would buy more wood than he would get in a month in that way
Walter has not calculated business as well and done as much work as I expected
Mr. Rivers boys talk strongly of going off west & I guess Mr. Kittridge will, to look & see how they like
Completed

I should think it would be well for Charles if he is coming home before winter, to come and be here a while before the ground freezes up i.e. if he means to carry on his farm next year -- he'll find things out of fix more than he expects perhaps I dont know but little about it, but it seems to me that clearing up that little patch of Alder was not very necessary

 O if Percie was smart & well as the Dear little Mayo. Nettie says he runs all about chasing the Butterflies, driving the Turkey etc. but I need not tell you for of course you hear of all his noble deeds. Albina has felt so bad herself that she has not told C so much about the children  Charlie is to come here and spend the winter unless his father decides differently. That was the calculation when we thought he was going to stay most all winter  he has been at his Grandfathers most of the time for weeks past which I regret exceedingly - the seed sown in his mind & heart among the boys there will be hard to eradicate a child at his age needs the constant watchfulness of a loving mother but I suppose A thought she couldn't very well have 'em both at home I wish he could have been here but it has not been consistent - it will be convenient now & he can help to amuse Percie & do some chores about the house but I expect if he'll need some training which L & I will endeavor to do as well as we can

I wish I could tell you how thankful I am that you are so willing to wrote letters to me when you get such poor returns God bless you both & keep you from all evil
Completed

Mother. Bangor Sept. 27, 1854
Dunbarton Sept 30, 1854
Bangor  Sept. 27th /54
My Dear Daughter
I feel that I owe an apology for not writing to you - I find myself more clumsy &, stupid about writing as I grow old - & when I am home especially I contrive to put it off on to Lucy as much as I can - If I could write, and could express my thoughts and feelings with as much ease & facility as you and Lucy can - I could better tell you how much I love & care for you & the Dear little Mayo - And how ardently I long to become more acquainted
But when I think of my absent ones and the Small prospect there is of my being with them much more and knowing their feelings their joys & their sorrows as I us'd to when they were all with me - My consolation is in the thought
Completed

that we may all meet in the "old mans Home" - a permanent home, where heart meets heart - where Sorrow and sickness and parting never come
O how thankful I ought to be (& I think I am) that I have such good children - all of them so good - How good & kind Isaac is about writing it is a great comfort to me - we had letters from him & Charles yesterday  Charles talks of coming home we shall expect him in a month or six weeks - I feel very much afraid he will be sick in consequence of coming so late in the season
Albina has worried so much about his coming home that he has concluded to come there is no doubt but that he wants to come enough but I believe he had thought it would be very much for his interest to stay till near Spring - I hope when Isaac comes you you & little Mayo come and stay a good long time  I do long so to be more acquainted with the baby Mayo  I dont know but he is getting to be too smart to be
Completed

call'd a baby  I was greatly amus'd to hear about his driving the Turkeys &c  No doubt but he's his Fathers own Child
How I do wish we could go to Dunbarton but the dear little Percie is so feeble that we have have no reason to expect he could bear the journey this fall - Lucy holds out wonderfully - but she looks as if she could not hold her head up or keep her eyes open - Percie is nervous & excitable it takes one of us all the time & sometime both to take care of him  Lucy has been so perfectly devoted to him & Sam'l too that I have feard he would be taken away on that very account  God requires of his children the whole heart but he is longsuffering & generous  you are very good & kind on writing to me when you get such poor returns it is a favor & a great gratification to me to hear from you - any thing which concerns you is interesting for me to know
My love & respects to your dear Parents  I wish we could have the pleasure of seeing them
Completed

here and your Brother and sister also  We had a letter from Albina tuesday little Mary was a good deal better tho' not quite well - we expect Charlie to come here in a week or two to stay a while perhaps all winter or till I go home  I dont know whether I shall stay here all the winter or not -
Yesterday Mrs. Carlastin Jewet and Miss Hannah Moore took tea with us   Eliab is gone to Boston  Maria and the little one are getting along nicely has not Eliab got a good wife? dont you love her I am sure I do & I wish I was more worthy of such good children as I have 
kiss the Dear little Mayo for me
your ever affectionate Mother
Completed

My Dear Sons                                                                                Bangor Oct. 14th 

                                  I have written to both of you not long since we have had letters from you both within a few days. I thank you very much for writing frequently.
  You complain of the irregularity of the Mails. It is bad enough at the best to be so far away that we cannot send & get a return in less than 3 or 4 weeks but I hope you will not always be so far away
  you speak of rain - we had had showers but not rain enough yet to raise the streams at all & the effect is very disastrous to Bangor. Some heavy failures I believe they say . S. & E. are trembling somewhat  I suspect.
 I feel sorry for your loneliness but you should not think about that. Be thankful instead that you have lov'd & loving ones to care for you & be care'd for.
 Didn't you rejoice when reading the account of the meeting of the "Board at Hartford I'm sure I did.

[left-hand side] we ve been expecting Charlie on every Stage Day guess he'll come next time
[top of letter upside down]O such a cunning little likeness of Mayo. I long to be more acquainted with the dear little fellow had a good letter from Nettie this week and from Anna
[bottom of letter upside down] Mother Bangor Oct. 14 1854

                                                                       "       28  "

How very thankful we ought to be that you both have been so well. Poor Mr. Rider Lucy has written all about it. It has been a trying scene for all of us. His countenance will be much disfigur'd but that is not the worst The Dr. told Sam'l that it was the worst kind of Caner i.e. in the skin to cure that it would probably break out again & eventually cause his death tis best not to intimate any such thing to them - very trying for Almeda as well as all the rest- by the way, Charles why have you not written to Almeda more? - tho' you have had a good many letters to write & you've done well - but perhaps she has not had her share. 

   Almeda has written to Sally to go take care for her while she is gone from home I suppose Walter will go from our home now they expect you home but George stays I suppose & they'll do well I guess I am sorry that you have been so harrass'd with news from home or for lack of the right news at the right time they have all been getting along well enough all the while if they could only think so May God be with you & keep you both in peace & safety & grant you every comfort till you meet again
                                                                                            your Mother

[top of letter upside down] I would not write to you when I am here as Lucy can do it all so much better were it not that I hope to get more letters by it.

Mother & Lucy
Nov. 14. 1854

                                                                                                               Bangor Nov. 14 -1854

My Dear Sons

               We had a letter from you Isaac a few days since giving an account of the shocking and most distressing R.R. accident Oh that poor young widow! How exceedingly Shock'd and distress'd you must have been & my Dear Son what a Solemn warning to you - "Be ye also ready,,
     I want to hear more particularly from you both I fear that I shall hear that you are Sick after so much excitement & fatigue.
  It does seem as if it must speak very plain to you "prepare to meet thy God,, Indeed we have all, at time reason enough, occation enough if we would heed it to feel there is but a step between us and death, & if we are indeed united to Christ by a living faith tis of little
Completed

consequence when or where or by what means we meet death

 Percie seems to be about well now and we are all in good health - we are having a fine rain such a rain as we have not had since last Spring. A very unusual and long drought  Sam'l is gone to Old Town today to see about his logs
 I suppose you hear from Milo frequently  Charlie came down here a week ago last Saturday they were all well then he is a pretty good boy but terribly full of business
 I want to know whether you and Charles are both coming home together, & whether you, your wife & baby will spend a good long time at Milo so that I can become acquainted with them
   Lucy is not quite as well as usual she does so frequently get too much fatigued before she is aware of it that I dont know as she ever will be well if she dont do better about it
Completed

Mother wished me to finish this I don't seem to have much to say. Don't know whether I am to blame for being so much of the time ailing - know that I have infirmities, both of body and spirit. But how dreadful the news in your last letter - how much more it has affected us than the death of hundreds or thousands in a more dreadful manner, if possible, in some other cases. It seems as though, we ought to bring thank offerings, as a family, for sparing and preserving mercy. Our little Percie is
Completed

nicely except his teeth - he has fourteen others badly swollen and troublesome Don't you think Mayo is quite behind? I hope he will not cut them harder for waiting. It is fortunate that it will probably be in cold weather. That is, unless he goes till another summer! He is more forward than Percie, as Nettie writes about him. Percie don't go out door alone at all. He tries to say a good many words, but hardly any plainly enough so that a stranger would understand. Charlie is a nice little boy; would superintend (advantageously, for aught I know) the general business of the family, if desired! I imagine his father wants to see him some, as well as the other children. He amuses Ellen, our girl very much - she thinks him a child needing care all the time, whereas he takes care of her almost & directs her famously. She laughs so hard once in a while. Ephraim Paulk, the builder of the palace on Boardway failed last week. Gets little sympathy. Be good & write often. Find up some curiosity & bring with you Charles, wont you? good bye - sis Lucy.
Completed

Mother Elyria Jan 2, 1856
Dunbarton Jan 26, 1856

                                                                                               Elyria Jan

My Dear Daughter

   I intended to have written to you sometime ago But you know how easily these short days slip away one after another. I suppose Isaac has written often & has inform'd you all about our journey & the dreadful scene at the Delavan House. What a merciful interposition of Providence - how can we be thankful enough that his dear life was saved. How quick is thought in my distress it seems as if I thought of almost everything ( while he lay talking incoherently without knowing what he said) of Paralasis & all dreadful sicknesses of his wife & dear little ones of my own helplessness. I didn't know at first that Coal Gas had any such effect.
 Isaac left here last Wednesday the 16th I cannot but feel anxious about him all
Completed

the time I know I need not for I suppose he is as capable of keeping himself out of danger as any body. But we are none of us our own keepers

 How I do want to see all the dear little boys. O may you all be kept in health
  I have seen but little of Elyria as yet I have had a cold & some headache the weather has been cold & stormy unusually so they say. Snow enough for good sleighing ever since I came here
  Anna has got a very pleasant and convenient house & indeed every thing she can reasonably want But her health is not quite as good as usual. She is thin of flesh and looks pale. But she does a good deal of work is flying round with great zeal every forenoon. I think she has work'd too hard the past few months repairing & altering the house has occation'd a great deal of fixing & arranging furniture fitting Carpets - Curtains etc. etc. etc.
Completed

She does most of her cooking herself i.e. she attends to & directs it all & labors vigorously about cakes & pies etc. Besides which she is giving lessons in French to Miss Woodbury & Hattie. Mrs. Woodbury has been here you know since last August she has lately commenced a school one of the public schools and boards here. She has rather an uncouth figure short & thick but a person of a fine mind very pleasant & agreeable.  Hattie attend the high school She has improv'd very much since I saw her. There are some things disagreeable in her manners now but I think she will make eventually a very fine character. The Doctor seems to be as happy as a man need wish to be. Libby is a little laughing frolicsome affectionate girl but greatly afflicted with weak eyes has been kept from school more than a year because of her eyes
Completed

Do my Dear Daughter let me hear from you often every thing you can tell me about the little ones or yourself and all the folks is interesting to me Tell Mayo Grandmother thinks of him everyday & wants him to be a very good obedient boy & very kind to the dear little Twins and go and play out in the barn alone and out doors when it is warm it will make him strong & healthy

  I have got some Delaine to put some new Sleeves in my black dress - have got a new black velvet Bonnet very plain & very much to my liking Anna did every thing about getting it made
 I shall always look back with pleasure on the time I spent at Dunbarton
 Much love & respect to your good Father & Mother & many kisses to the little boys.  I feel quite at home already expect to pass my time very pleasantly surely God has been very good to me. in the afflictions of my like he has remembered mercy  from your loving Mother 
                                                                                                                                                           A.M.M.
Completed

Elyria Jan. 27 1856

My Dear Son 

   I am very much oblig'd to you for your letter of Jan. 20th (at Ducoign) also for one reciev'd some days before written at Chicago   You seem to have snowstorms where ever you go. It has been very cold here & Stormy most of the time.  I had a letter from Lucy Dated Jan 19  They were all well then Hattie Ely & Eliabs baby had a narrow escape She fell down the back stairs with baby in her arms in the dark She was bruis'd considerably but baby was not hurt.  Mr. Rider & Almeda were there again to see Dr. M Ruen He thinks best not to perform another opperation on that place under his jaw as present is trying to heal without  Walter Rider is at his Fathers all this winter Lame having cut his leg just above the knee in the woods
Completed

He suffer'd a great deal before they could get him home Dr. MRuen thinks Mr. Riders health every way improv'd - imputes it to vegatable diet & Drinking Ale Mr. Rider thinks it Dr. Greens medicine

 I have a letter from Nettie dated 21st the Children are well - all the folks getting along nicely  I think you need not feel at all troubled about the folks at home however much you may want to see the Babies
 My health is pretty good -Cold almost gone have not been out to meeting till yesterday because of the cold stormy weather
 A letter came here directed to you from your Friend Mitchell  he Mailed at Bangor had been there some time I guess Date Dec. 23 I suppose it is of no great consequence to you now as you have seen him
 with much love and prayer for your safety and happiness
                                                                                                                  your Mother
Completed

I hope you have not yet sent any to Bangor  & will not without a special charge.

Mother Elyria Ohio
March 12-18, 1856

                                                                                    Elyria March 12th / 56

My Dear Son  I have been thinking a good deal about you of late, as usual.  Shall feel a little more anxious as I doubt not you do because of your not knowing exactly what is to be your future course or place of residence - you could settle down in Dunbarton or in almost any other place. And if faithful as a Christian be useful & happy. But it seems to me that with your knowledge of western life you might & ought with your experience your ability & your energy of Will & Character to take upon you the battle of life in some place where you can do the most good.

  There is a trait or spot or whatever you please to call it in you which inclines you to settle down below what you might and ought to attain to ("come honestly by it,, perhaps, Charles and Almeda also) you ought to guard against it. One way is to strive for such a position in life that you will be call'd upon - necessitated - to act I dont meant physically, only but Morally Intellectually. It is not right for you to think that you may live only for yourself & your family. Not that I think you do so more than others but that
Completed

but that you are more to be blam'd if you do, why? because it is worse to bury five talents than one
Rouse up then place yourself where there is a great deal of good to be done and do it.

 I greive to think of your Christian influence and progress in the divine life compar'd with what it might & ought to be. If you will have the earnest

deeptan'd piety and hearty endeavers, what an influence for good you might wield in the brest?. Tis your duty & your privelege, do it "life is earnest life is real". There I have written what I happen'd to be thinking & you may well say what a fool! to be so much like a Guide board

 When I look back (from the end of the track or doubtless very near it) and see how little - how less than nothing of what I ought to have done & might have done by the help of divine grace which would have been granted if earnestly enough sought for It makes me very anxious that my Children should do some good in the world should make up my lack of service I feel that I have not done what I could tho' what I could was so little
  We have been reading Biographical Sketches & Sermon of Mr. Reuben Tinker with much pleasure and with edification I hope
Completed

13th March
 I have been looking for a letter from you this sometime. I feel confident there is one on the way the Mails have been very irregular. The Dr. has just been to the P.O. & come back with the usual story no Mail. News by Telegraph that there was not Mail east or west for 50 hours from Buffalo and Storming still. Anna had another Party a few days since The Minister the Mayor the judge members of Congress & the elite to the number of 35 or 40. The Tea sent served Oyster Soup biscuit & butter Cold Meat (cut thin as a wafer) Cheese pickles jelly & Cake in variety and abundance - a very pleasant time very good pleasant people Anna & Dr. seem to be lov'd and look'd up to by all the People round, & they treat me with very mark'd respect for their sake.
  I begun this some days ago & have been waiting & waiting to hear from you before I send it
 We have seen a good many notices of Home all pretty good or indifferent except one in the "Criterion N.Y.,, which was quite severe & rather unfair - call'd it "dull as directory" & much else as bad. Anna felt highly gratified the last sentence from the Sandusky Register -"Lady of Oberlin,, & then taken all aback by a little in a Cleaveland paper - "Lady of Elyria; however there is a good many ladies in Elyria.

I send you some slips cut from Newspapers if you think best send them to L. when you have read 'em
Completed

If I dont get a letter from you today I shall send this along to find out the reason I have had a little touch of Rheumatism it was as much as I could do to get up out of my chair but am much better today

  The Dr. & Anna talk of going to Illinois (Tiskilwa) to see Dewies the latter part of spring & say that if Sam'l & Lucy will come here they will go up to St. Paul as the Dr. says he means to see that region some time. I have written to Lucy to let us know whether they can go this Spring. Dewee writes a letter to his Father "We thank Mother for her kind sympathies and believe her one of the best of Mothers &  choice blessing to a family. We love her in every sense of the word. We did not believe there could be such a Mother found who would steal the affections of every one who knew her.

March 18th

   I just recieved your letters which I have been so long waiting for and must hurry to get this in the Mail tonight am so glad to hear that you are all well love to all the folks 

Do write oftener to your Mother
Completed

Elyria May 2nd / 56

My Dear Son

  I recieved your letter on the 29 just five days after the date of it. The last I rec'd from Bangor was 9 days on the way I thank you very much for your promptness in writing  And for your very kind offer to meet us on the way. We now think of Starting Tuesday morning 13th of May. I am afraid it is too early in the season but there are reasons why it is most convenient to go then unless we put it off till the 26 or 27 And that would make Anna's visit very shorty as the Dr. thinks he must be back by 1st of July because of his business in the Bank. we shall endeavor & get through Tickets to Boston and stop there a day or two & Anna thinks we can get along to Parkers without you coming to meet us as it will save so much expense. Then we hope you can go to Bangor with us.
 I cant of course tell you now when we shall be at Parkers but perhaps we can let you know after we get to Boston.  The grass is up looking very green & beautiful. The leaves are out on the apples tree so that they look quite
Completed

Mother M. Elyria 

  May 2 - 1856

Dunbarton
green the cherry trees in bloom but the Peach trees the Dr. says are as good as dead some few of them perhaps will put out a few leaves but no blossom

 Anna is very much "driv, fixing dresses bonnets etc. etc. for her girls & her own things for her journey. We have had some very warm days but today (& most of the days) there is a Cold wind from the lake that makes a fire very comfortable. I wish I could tell you just when we shall all get along so that you could be at Parkers. But we cannot even tell what shall be in the Morrow.
 I suppose if we go so early the Earth & the Trees will hardly have got on their Spring dress  In much haste with much love to you all from your Mother
                        If you are writing to Lucy please tell her we are coming
Completed

My Dear Son I will just say that we now expect to start from Cleaveland on Wednesday at 3 or 4 oclock in the Lightening express train& go right on to Boston without stopping  I dont think it would be any harder than to stop at any Hotel on the way without any Gentleman to take care of us, therefore if we have no disaster or unexpected delay we will be at Parkers Saturday i.e we expect to get into Boston Thursday night Spend one day there & go to D. Saturday. It is barely possible that we might spend the Sabbath in B. if Mrs. C. Chase who Anna wishes to see is yet living there
I receiv'd a letter from Lucy last night poor girl how much she suffers with cough & pain in her side I feel very anxious about her.  And in haste to get there Am expecting you will go with us to Bangor
Completed

Dunbarton

    I am some afraid this will not reach you soon enough for you to meet us at Parkers  but we can find some way to get along
  If it should so happen that we dont get to Boston till friday night we may conclude to spend the Sabbath there. But in regard to all this you know I can only guess . Much love to you all from your Mother

Mother Bangor Me.
June 15 1856
Dunbarton

    Bangor June 15th / 56
  Tis Sunday night 10 oclock - but I feel as if I must write a little at least begin a letter to you my Dear Isaac & Nettie I ought perhaps to have written to you before but there seems to be something all the time to do. Beside I have rather a bad cold & Anna & Lucy would feel rather bad if they did not think that I was in bed. I suppose you want very much to hear from Lucy. But I hardly know what to tell you. Her cough & ? seem to be about the same except that twice since you were here she has spit up some blood and bad looking matter, & here she has had severe pain in her side which lasted 2 or 3 hours at a time so severe she could not but ?? Dr. DeWitt says he cannot tell - but he thinks that her lungs are not as yet affected but that it is all oaccasion'd by the excessive irritation of the stomach etc. He recommends injections of Meat Broth with a little anodyne Laudenum or something of the kind - think we shall try it as it seems as it could do no harm. She does not seem so strong as when I first came here but she does not seem to have so much fever as she had perhaps this is the reason that she appears more languid. She is greatly afflicted with pain & aches in many
Completed

but we have hope that all may yet be well

  The things have come up nicely in the Garden but they need the hoe badly Sam'l has to be awake? a great deal? nights & has a great deal to discourage him every way. Charles came down with Anna Friday after you left. I was very glad you went to Lowel why didn't you tell me something more about I.M. Metcalf's family & where Caleb, Enoch, & Charles are. Eliab had a letter from your uncle Pelahah Peletiah he complains that he has heard nothing from our family for a long time. The Dr. arriv'd here last Thursday night. Can it be a whole fortnight since you went away. I'm sorry I haven't written sooner will try to do better. God bless you & keep you from all evil.  Much love to Dear little Mayo to the little babies and to you all from
                                                                                                                                                     your Mother
Completed

[right-hand side] Mother Bangor Me. 

July 3, 1856

Dunbarton

                                                                                                   Bangor July 3rd / 56

My Dear Son

  I believe I have not had an answer to my last letter to you. I feel very anxious to hear from you & yours of your excursion to the white mountains etc.
  I suppose you would like to hear from Lucy but I hardly know what to tell you. Now & then a day she seems to be getting better. But I cant perceive that she has gain'd strength any & I am sure she has been losing flesh all the while her cough dont seem now quite so bad as it has been. She raises about as much she has rais'd bad looking matter - green & dark some blood some pain in her side occasionally very severe which gets relieved after a few hours by means of
Completed

hot mustard Poultice her food does not trouble her quite as much since she has strawberries green Peas etc. & her appetite is good. It seems as if she would gain strength some if she could keep her food down

 I have not been out since I came here except one afternoon to meeting & once to ride awhile with Eliab. I might have gone more but didn't feel like it
 Mallie took Percy down street yesterday got a very fine likeness of him to send to Minnesota
 Mary Ely & Family Beach are having a fine time riding about etc. 

4th Eliab himself for a wonder & Maria call'd up here this morning & brought your letter what a fine time you must have had but how is it possible that Ann could have endur'd so much fatigue I am afraid she and the
Completed

Dr. too will be sick a month to pay for it I think they'll not have much time to spend at Saratoga and get home at the time he propos'd to

 What is the matter with Nettie tell her I went to know more particularly about her health. Do the babies begin to want to run alone any
 Tell Mayo that Percy has got a beautiful little house Noah's Ark his Uncle DeWitt give it to him with one hundred Beasts & Birds of every Shape & hue they look real cunning I have laid away a great proportion of them for their horns & legs & tails are so easily broken he has mutilated almost all of those he has had to play with

[upside down] Percy was standing when having his likeness taken it is a very good one if you have one of Mayo let him be standing
Completed

I have felt very much discourag'd about Lucy sometimes and she has about herself tho' she is you know very hopeful - one day she wanted me to bring her the looking Glass after looking I said in a careless manner - well what do you think of yourself - a sad look came over her face & she answer'd  I think I shall never get well that is what I think
 But for 2 or 3 days past she does certainly seem to be better she may be all down again by tomorrow but I feel very much encouraged now Strawberries & green Pea seem to set better on her stomach than anything she has had Do my Dear Children write often let me know your thoughts & feelings & plans much love to your Parents, & you call from your
                                                                                                       Mother

Dunbarton                                                                                             Bangor July 22nd / 56
