She has had spells of very acute pain in her side which lasts 1, 2 or 3 days & then subsides a little leaving her weak & languid her cough & raising continues about the same only of late 2 weeks it causes such excruciating pain in her left shoulder& vomiting 3 or 4, or 6 or 8 times a day & it is so distressing when she does tis so hard we
Completed

we have to hold on to her back & shoulder I have felt very much discourag'd about her - have sometimes fear'd that she could not live but a short time But she is yesterday & today a little more comfortable
She can take no medicine everything the least particle almost nausiates the Dr. says tis sympathy with the diseas'd state of the Lungs that makes such a state of the stomach. Whether she is spar'd to us or not I fear she has got to endure a great deal of suffering. Dear patient uncomplaining Child

 Pray for her my Children- & for me that my health & strength may hold out. It helps me be thankful that I can be with her take care of her She has burning fever in the afternoon with the hectic flush, swell'd feet & sweating dreadfully when she sleeps has to sit up most all of the time because of her cough
Completed

Thursday morning
24th Lucy remains a little more comfortable slept last night better than she has for considerable time. I feel some encourag'd about her as I have a day or two at a time often before. O if it could but last

 I suppose you have been inform'd that Charles & albina came down made us a good visit on the 8th stay'd 2 nights

9th Mr. Rider Almeda (& Elbridge to bring them) came Lucy got very tir'd before they got fixt away to Boston Mr. R. decided to go & see Dr. Green of Boston I have great fears that he had better not have gone & it is very strange that we have not heard from them yet

 I have got very weary sometimes not but that the spirit has been always willing but I feel pretty well now and able to do what L needs & it is so much pleasanter for her & me than for anybody else to
Completed

It seems to relieve her nervousness? to be rubbed & her feet & hand bathed which we do often every day. Lizzie has improv'd greatly she is a great help to me she has a vacation now of seven weeks - & I think we shall keep her at home next term if Lucy is not better much love to you all do write often let me know your plans and thoughts & doings
May God bless you & keep you in health and from all evil
Tell Mayo I want very much to see him & the little Twins please kiss them all for me
Completed

Dear Isaac & Nettie

 I suppose Sam'l has written & kept you inform'd in regard to Lucy our altimate hopes & fears today we have a little hope - her cough is the same - but she seems a little stronger. If she gets well it will seem like raising from the dead almost Tis astonishing beyond measure that her strength holds out as it does. Such pain and suffering & raising such quantities of such bad matter. She herself is very hopeful. She said to me this morning O how wonderful that my baby is alive Tis a happiness almost greater than I can bear if it should die it seems as if I couldn't live & I really think that her strong hope & happiness in her child has help'd greatly to sustain her life
Completed

the little one is nam'd (by her Mother, Allice DeWitt. I wish you could see it --dear birdie I feed it by doubling a little fine rag & out one end in its mouth & let the other lay in a Teaspoon of cream & water till she sucks it all out which one teaspoonful once an hour is all I give her at once
How wonderful that I can take the care of it - necessity - you know The little thing seems well performs all the functions of babyhood I wash'd it all over (except the bowels) this morning & drest it you cannot think how difficult it is to keep it warm (I have a fire on purpose) I have an old soft silk Hkf around its feet a silk Hkf too for a blanket with a flannel one over it it is a very perfect Child - has a very pretty face  We have a strong capable Nurse who takes care of Lucy & I devote my time to baby - but with fear & trembling almost it is so little
Completed

I have thought much about your going away west how I wish you could consistently come here. But as Sam'l says there seems to be no inducement except to be near the rest of the family he says there seems to be nothing you could do to advantage I should be so glad to have you if it could be best but I suppose it is not a very healthy place Eliab says he means to get away from here on that account but perhaps he is unnecessarily alarm'd just bow. He got his family off down river to preserve their health baby was not well & yesterday he heard that Maria is sick he went right down last evening has not return'd will come tomorrow morning I suppose 
I had a letter from Anna - she says Isaac has not answer'd the Drs. Letter yet } Love to your father & Mother & to all the folks from your loving Mother
Completed

August 10th Lucy says she feels more comfortable today than for four days past which is very encouraging O if it were not for her Cough and distress for breath but yet I feel there is hope
A letter from Mr. rider yesterday his face is swolen more but not more painful
[left side]  Mother   Bangor
Aug. 10 1856
Dunbarton
Completed

Bangor Aug 17

To Isaac & Nettie

   Dear Lucy & baby are living yet I have written a week how great hopes that L might get better but our hopes grow fainter - our fears stronger she has been comparatively free from pain has rais'd freely with her effort & her strength held out remarkably her feet didn't swell as much - her bowels in good order. But the last 3 days she has a Diarrhea - & to check it she is kept constantly under the influence of Opium is almost all the time in an unquiet restless sleep - her feet are swelling again she dont say much about herself O I suppose we must believe that the time is short with her - is not our time short too are we not all passing away

[top of letter upside down]her pulse has been 140 now 120 the Dr. says
Completed

If you go west this fall to go into any business there, you must leave your family you cannot be with them could only see them oftener if you take them with you. As you must leave them why not at Milo with Charles if they were further off they might ? ? he would do everything for them that he could - however I do not feel comfortable to advise

 I have no time to write more baby is sick with Cholera in ? she is too little & feeble she cannot live long if not better soon O how I want to see you and all

My Prayer for dear Lucy is not so much now for her life but that she may feel more sensibly the encircling arms of her Savior about her - not but that I can feel that she is wash'd in His Blood that cleanseth from all sin her wonderful Patience & meekness under such dreadful sufferings evince it 

                                                                                                  from your loving Mother
Completed

[right-hand side] Mother Sept. 5 1856
Bangor Dunbarton

                                                                                                                 Sept. 5, 1856

My Dear Children

 I suppose you want to hear from Bangor & think as you begin to read this that you have a letter but you'll find is poor apology for one tho' I feel a good deal better and stronger than when you were here I am so stupid & dull I can hardly think. I want very much to hear from you to know whether you are going to Elyria or what you are going to do. Sam'l has spoken to Eliab about coming up here to live would like to have him - & it seems as if would be very much for his benefit to do so save him a great deal of expense. S. propos'd to have them keep house & we board with them would finish a sleeping room in back chamber it would save 175, rent and as much in hir'd help in the two families but Mallie does not incline to it
Completed

I should think that Eliab would like it but I guess she will not consent to it - thinks it would be too much care etc.

  It is doubtful whether I can get a girl as housekeeper that will not need some looking after & surely it would be very queer for me at my age to attempt to "guide the house besides the care of this little one Tis true God is able to give me Strength & wisdom to do it as He is able to perform any other Miracle. I trust there will be some way found out I expect disagreebles & Trials in whatever way unless indeed it should so turn out that you'd bring Nettie here which I do not wish you to do if it would be to your detriment . If you do find a good Chance at Elyria & feel that it is best for you to go west
Completed

I would have you go - We are getting along nicely at present  Caddie performs her part very well  I make out to get sleep enough while the Babe sleeps - The week that you were here & the 2 or 3 weeks before were very very hard for me  I wonder I did n't quite break down under it - But the generous  Promise is & will be fulfils - 'As the day is so shall thy strength be' I do not mourn I felt a solemn quiet resignation - Almost Joy that Dear Lucy, Suffering and conflicts are all over that she has arriv'd to that heaven where I hope to be & the time is short even if I should live to endure many days of pain & suffering in my turn all things are passing away they will soon be gone
Do write frequently I thank Nettie for her good letter receivd
Completed

last night - Lizzie Page died Tuesday night was buried yesterday was deranged almost all the time she was sick
Lizzie stays here she commenced going to school this week
The Dear little Babe is not quite a well these 2 days past seems more feeble & languid sleeps a great deal but dont take its food so well wakes a little and stretches & makes up all manner of faces  I hope it is not going to be sick
How I should love to see those little boys. The Twins will run alone by the time they are a year old wont they? I think that is pretty well for 8 months babies  It will be less work to take care of them when they can walk but you'll need your eyes about you then too
remember me to your Father Mother & much love to you all from your
Mother
Completed

Sept. 6 I got your letter this this morning Think you must had a very hard time getting home I guess as Mayo was so sick Nettie was glad. Baby seems quite well this morning & my health is very good I beg you would not be anxious about my health. The wonder is not that I was almost sick when you were here - but that I was not clear broken down Think what I've had daily ever since I came from Elyria and the increas'd anxiety labor ad excitement of the last 5 or 6 weeks before Lucy died more than you can think or know

 In regard to taking care of Baby - I have long ago thot of my age as the objection & almost the only one & that is bot as if I was not
Completed

health few people enjoy better health & what might be gain'd by having a younger nurse might be lacking in affectionate interest I shall soon manage it so as not to have the infant sleep very near to me only so that I can reach it,. It was Lucys earnest request that I should take it said she had thought a great deal but could think of no other way so good I think her prayers will be answered and I shall have the health and strength requisite to the task 

 Pray for me my Dear Children & may God bless you & guide you in all the way you go

I have made out something of a letter after all I think I have ascertained the real reason why they dont want to come here is Hattie scruples foolish ones too I recon she wants to stay with Maria but would not like to come for certain reasons!!!
Completed

Mother  Bangor
Sept. 10 1856
Dunbarton

                                                                                                             Bangor Sept. 10th / 56

My Dear Dear Children

    O that I could say something to comfort you. But I can only point up - the way you know "narrow but pleasant way" yet alas tis easier to say be reconcil'd than to fully & freely feel "Thy will O God be done. I had so long seen that it must be do - that I was in same sort reconcil'd to Lucy's death. But this sharp sudden blow. Dear precious Mayo I hope not to murmer but I did so doat on him - I dar'd not say how much. But still the heaviest of it is what I feel for you. I am smitten too in another branch my dear little Lucy that has these five weeks past fill'd
Completed

my mind with tender care & love was taken too this morning about 7 oclock It had been failing about a week with the Bowel Complaint did not seem to suffer very much except the last two days. O how lonely the house does seem I hardly know what to do with myself I shall think of, & miss Dear Lucy much more now. But O how my heart bleeds for you so much of hope & promise so suddenly remov'd. But this is not our home let us garner our hopes & treasures there where sorrow & sickness never come where so many Dear Ones are already gather'd about the throne singing redeeming love. I do pray for you & I beg you to pray for me that I may mind my pace and not grow dull and faint by the way

 Much love to you all from your Mother
Completed

Sept. 14 1856

I didn't feel the extent of my loss when Lucy was first taken away - my mind was all absorb'd with the thought that her dreadful suffering was ended that she had enter'd the realms of bliss a glorified spirit I never before had so great a sense of the unspeakable happiness of being in Christ & with Christ

 And now I do not murmer but I do mourn I feel her loss more & more every day every thing reminds me of her. How many times in a day I want her opinion & advice 
 Do you remember how she always seem'd to see at a glance just how every thing ought be & how much we depended on her opinion, how can I get along without her
 But it is all right I would not
Completed

if I could call her back for a thousand words.

    May God enable us to forget the things that are behind and press forward toward the mark - the time is short - Pray for me
 O how I wish you had had Mayo's likeness taken when he was here. But I will try to be thankful - thankful that you had such a boy & that I had the happiness of being with him as much as I did  Wednesday morning

Sept. 17th Reciev'd your letter this morning O my Dear Children - How you are afflicted. But is it not well? Should He not do what he will with his own? We are fast being gathered home O may we at length all be there not one missing
O if it might please Him to spare his hand to let it suffice. But
Completed

I do so fear for the rest of you for you my Dear Dear Son you must be by this time all worn out with watching anxiety & fatigue a

afternoon Mallie has just been in here & talks that they have about concluded to come up here I feel more miserably about it than I did before - at first I wanted they should - thought it would be better for them But now I feel as if they/ Mallie & Hattie) do not want too they have all along been finding up excuses for not coming - but feel as if they must. I feel more of constraint with them than with you & Nettie but perhaps it will wear off. But I can hardly think of any thing but you & your affliction if you should be taken sick do please Telegraph to Eliab at once & he will go to you

 Have you a good physician what do you do - what do you take
Completed

Mr. Riders face has grown worse very fast he cannot quite shut his teeth together Almeda thinks it will be thro' into his mouth soon smells is I suppose exceedingly offensive his life will probably not be long nor it is desirable it should be, as it must be a burden to himself

 This is a time of sorrow Lucy Mayo Dear little baby & little sweet Willie whose turn will come next O God make us submissive and Patient under thy repeated shakes & if consistent with thy Holy will stay thine hand 

Shall you move away let us hear from you often
God bless & keep you my dear children              A.M. Metcalf
Mother    Bangor
Sept. 14 1856 Dunbarton
Completed

[right side]  Mother    Bangor
Sept. 20, 1856 Dunbarton

                                                                                                                                  Friday 20 Sept. / 56

Dear very Dear Isaac  I do feel so thankful that you are such a good boy about writing I have just read a letter which Eliab took from the Office last night dated 24th Sept.

   Am very glad to hear that the sick are recovering I have many fears that you have not seen the worst of it as to yourself. Do be careful of yourself. It would be wonderful if you do escape a fit of sickness after tending upon the sick so much - so much watching & anxiety - anxiety & excitement is perhaps what has kept you up till now. I am sure if you are not sick you must need a long time to recruit & get your usual health & strength. I should think that George would come & stay till
Completed

his Father & Mother get well especially if it is necessary for you to go away bye & bye Is there any probability that it will be expedient for you to bring Nettie here to stay this winter & perhaps next summer it would be exceeding pleasant to me i e if it would be advantageous and agreeable to her & you

 If we have nobody here but we four S. & P.P. Lissie & I - I shall try to get along without any hir'd help My health is good & growing better think I can do what is necessary (hire the washing) quite comfortably with what Lissie can help. But if it would accord with your other arrangements should be so glad to have Nettie here 

we have suppos'd that if Nettie gets well enough & you go west that it would be so happen that Nettie & the dear little one that is left would go & stay with Anna
Completed

Eliabs babe has been more unwell of late & they have just decided that they will come up here with him & stay while I am gone to Milo. Eliab thinks it is a great deal more healthy here than where he lives. We expect to go to Milo next week weather permitting
 It has rain'd almost all this week.

Monday morning 29th a fine clear cool morning we've had not frost here yet to injure the vines or anything till last night & has only just crush'd the top of the leaves a little now we've had & are having a profusion of Tomatoes many more than we can use 3 kinds the red yellow & grape. Eliabs Family have not mov'd but have come up here with the baby to stay a while he is better but has grown very poor has got 3 teeth & 2 or 3 more badly swell'd I expect S. will carry Percie & I to Milo someday this week.
Completed

Eliab has had an ill turn Diarrhea has not been quite well for a good while - his hair is all coming off. He has had it cut off very short but it does not stop it coming out yet perhaps it will. I just had a letter from Sister Conant she wrote me about a Medicinal Spring - a sick man Mr. David dream'd about it found it and was cur'd - it is on the Walls place just a S.W. of Father Rich's farm- hundreds visit there daily. Some men in Boston have bought the land & are putting up large buildings. Tis notic'd in the Puritan perhaps you've seen something of it Sister says she dont perceive that the water is different from any other clear spring water.
30th I have delay'd sending this till I reciev'd the Bundle which S. has just brought home I have put on to P.P. a pr of the pants & a ? they fit exactly will save us work & expense very much obliged for them
Sympathy & much love to Nettie & all the folks shall feel anxious till I hear again.
[right-hand side] but hope you and all very much better your ever loving Mother
Completed

Mother Bangor
Sept. 21 1856
Dunbarton
I thank you my dear good boy for your good long letter to me & to Eliab of 16th & Sam'l of the 18  O that I could do or say any thing to comfort you my Dear Children  Sorely afflicted indeed you are poor Nettie but let me remind her to be thankful that you are spar'd to her - from my own experience I can feel that the loss of all her dear children would be lighter than that - I shall feel very anxious till I hear that she is recovered  I have many fears too for your Mother Putnam she is so feeble  But those dear beautiful boys I feel deeply my own loss & feel it doubly in feeling it for you too - But let it serve to lessen the cords that bind us to Earth  & fix our thoughts more intently on that dear home where all tears are wiped away & the inhabitants shall no more say I am sick
I can hardly imagine where your sick have all been located - none up stairs I suppose?
Completed

I have been planning about Percies winter clothes but have done nothing as yet he wears his little baby dresses under his aprons but they are getting to be not warm enough  I shall have time enough to fit for him now the Dear little baby is taken from me  I did look for a great deal of comfort & satisfaction in taking care of it but it has gone to its mother & doubtless is ten thousand times better off than it could be in this world of sin & sorrow
I am expecting to go to Milo with Percie to stay a few weeks probably in a week or 10 days - Sam'l & Lizzie stay at Eliabs the while  I hope to hear from you often while there
much love to all the folks from
your ever loving Mother
Completed

Mother  Milo Maine
Oct. 20th 1856
Dunbarton
Milo Oct. 20th 1856
My Dear Children
I thank you very much for Netties good letter of Oct. 7th  what warm weather we have had almost all this month  I have been helping Albina was today Tis more than I have done at that business in all the time that I have been gone from here  I find my strength is very much less than it was last summer  I have grown older but my health is very good for a person of my age I think  I have been here 2 weeks today  begin to feel quite at home again - I always feel a little discontented & uneasy a few days when I first come home after being gone for some time - Percie is just as happy & contented as a child could be ever since he has been here he & Mary agree very well
Mary is now a very smart & good little girl. The children very often speak of Mayo  Dear little Mayo how much I did love him - hardly an hour in the day but he has been in my thoughts since I have been here - But let us rejoice that he and the
Completed

other dear ones that have gone are safe in our Fathers house in the blissful presence of Him that died that we might live
I hope the dear little Wilder will soon have his teeth through & be well  I should think that change of air and more yet change of scene would benefit your health - James is here yet is very steady and attentive to his business he has not been home since last April  The little boys have improved in their behavior I think. Charlie has rais'd by his own labor 2 bushels of potatoes about one bushel of Beans & some carrots &c. He prepares to devote a part of his revenue to benevolent purposes is going to buy some little Books for distribution & feels the importance of his transactions considerably he gives Joseph a share of his profits tho' he says he so lazy that he did nt help him hoe but little
Josie is a smart strong boy to work when he has a mind to - Albina's health seems quite as good as it was last summer notwithstanding she is 3 months along She has done all her housework except that Mrs Calors help'd her work a few weeks in the summer
Completed

I feel sorry for Mary She is a real good affectionate little girl - but she gets scolded so much & for what she can hardly help doing - She teases her Mother a good deal to let her be a boy yesterday she got on a hat & one of the boys old jackets & so we call'd her John  her Mother went to the door a while after & found she had an axe chopping away on a stick of wood & call'd to her to come away  she said my name is n't Mary I'm John, cant I chop if I'm John
I have delay'd sending my letter to the PO by one mail hoping to get a letter from Isaac before sending it - Have been cutting out Jackets for Charlie & Josie out of Charles wedding coat got them both out nicely after some contriving with Albina to help  There is work enough here to do Albina has a lot of sewing to do  I've a chance to send to the PO this minute So good bye
with much love to you all
Mother
